OTHER fashion designers have chic, have irony, have elegance, have attitude. Cynthia Rowley has what you might call boing -- a Spring-O-Lator sense of silliness that, combined with her youthful silhouettes, bright colors and inexpensive but idiosyncratic detailing, adds up to a pretty charming whole.

This is, after all, a woman who chose to take a tricked-up circus-knife-thrower's target board along when she was having her photo taken by the serious portraitist Timothy Greenfield-Sanders. She wanted to be immortalized as a lovely but nervous knife-thrower's assistant.

''Well, I asked him if I could bring a prop, and he said yes,'' she explained. And instead of penning a book about her experience in fashion, she has blithely rewritten (and illustrated) her life story as a fantastical children's book cum memoir, ''Slim: A Fantasy Memoir,'' out this month from Rizzoli.

So it is fitting that while the sociable Ms. Rowley is frequently happy, she is happiest bouncing on the 12-foot High Jump trampoline she has in the backyard of the West Village town house she shares with her husband and two young daughters.

''It was always my dream to have one when I was little, because Pam Posey had one -- she was fancy,'' she said, referring to her best friend. ''I'm always fulfilling all these childhood dreams I had.''

It certainly makes her easy to shop for. About 15 years ago, when her business was taking off, her staff pitched in and bought her a trampoline, which she installed at the house she then had in upstate New York. Three weeks later, a Harper's Bazaar photographer shot her jumping on it in a pink ball gown, and she got tangled up in the tulle and broke her arm.

Undeterred, she bought another trampoline years later when she purchased a beach shack in Montauk, and recently bought another one for her Village house, where she and her daughters have had to keep their ebullience somewhat in check.

''We do live in a neighborhood where you have to be kind of quiet,'' she said. ''So we're out there before school at 8 in the morning, and I'm always saying, 'Shhh.' I'm sure someone's going to complain about the giggling.''

On the plus side, she finds she can see into her neighbors' backyards (and second floors) with ease. ''I can almost get up to a third-floor walk-up,'' she boasted. ''I saw a woman in her underwear, but it wasn't that interesting.''

As irreverent as this suspension of all gravity sounds, Ms. Rowley has turned her colorful spirit into a major business that she owns, a rarity in fashion. But the trampoline is not a piece of brand identity. ''It's been with me my whole life -- at least, the desire to have one as a kid, and then getting it as an adult,'' she said. ''We had our wedding picture taken on it.'' Or rather, above it.

And one of her favorite books is ''Philippe Halsman's Jump Book,'' a 1959 collection of photographs in which Halsman captured luminaries like Marilyn Monroe, Richard Nixon and Salvador Dal√≠ in midair. In a sudden burst of energy, Halsman wrote, explaining the jump's appeal, ''the real self becomes visible.''

But Ms. Rowley may argue that jumping makes her real self visible all day long. ''There's just an exuberance you get,'' she said. ''It's not like I can do a lot of tricks, but you can't help but laugh when you're jumping.''
In this house, not taking things seriously is taken very seriously.
